quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: When the CDC mandated face masks in early April 2020, that's when essentially we went to sleep one day with our typical April traffic, typical April sales, and then it was Black Friday overnight.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A vivid example of how external shocks can instantly transform marketplace demand and require rapid operational/product response.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Our sellers are incredibly astute business people. And if you had been making wedding dresses, and you know how to sew, and you've got material, and you've got a bit of time, making a mask is quite a simple task. And so we just saw this huge surge of demand, and then supply rising to meet it.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Highlights a marketplace dynamic practitioners can leverage: flexible supply can rapidly retool when sellers have transferable capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And we did something that as far as I know, we've never done in Etsy's past, which is we put out a call to our sellers to say, "Now's the time. Now's the time to make face masks if you can."
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Actionable playbook: directly mobilize supply with a clear call-to-action during demand spikes, even if it breaks precedent.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Tim is VP of product at Etsy, where he's been for over 10 years, and has helped grow Etsy from around 500 million in GMV to over 13 billion in GMV.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete growth data point that frames the scale of Etsy’s evolution and the experience behind the episode’s lessons.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It helps ensure roadmaps drive revenue, by instantly aligning product with your sales and marketing teams to capture upsell opportunities.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (productroadmap.ai / Ignition read)
quotes.context: Actionable framing for tying product roadmaps directly to revenue outcomes via cross-functional alignment and upsell capture.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: it automatically identifies feature gaps from your CRM data and your customer conversations, adds them to shareable roadmaps, easily prioritized by revenue impact, and then seamlessly closes the loop with sales reps via targeted notifications when feature gaps are closed.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (productroadmap.ai / Ignition read)
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for turning customer/CRM signals into a revenue-prioritized roadmap and a feedback loop back to sales.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Wherever you work, running experiments is increasingly essential, but there are no commercial tools that integrate with a modern growth team stack.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo read)
quotes.context: A pointed observation about experimentation maturity being bottlenecked by tooling integration gaps in modern stacks.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo lets you go beyond basic click through metrics, and instead use your north star metrics like activation, retention, subscription, and payments.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo read)
quotes.context: Practical guidance to evaluate experiments against north-star business metrics rather than shallow engagement proxies.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo supports tests on the front end, on the backend, email marketing, even machine learning claims.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo read)
quotes.context: Specific example of broad experimentation surface area, encouraging teams to test beyond UI changes.

quotes.topic_title: Leaving Etsy for SoulCycle and returning
quotes.text: Ultimately realized it wasn't a place that I wanted to spend a ton of time and energy. And so through a lot of soul-searching, grown, I know I found my way back to Etsy, really anchoring on three things.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A practical decision framework for evaluating (and re-evaluating) career moves based on explicit anchors rather than momentum.

quotes.topic_title: Leaving Etsy for SoulCycle and returning
quotes.text: One, working on a product that you care about that adds value to other people's lives.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A simple criterion practitioners can use to assess role fit and motivation: mission/value alignment with real user impact.

quotes.topic_title: Leaving Etsy for SoulCycle and returning
quotes.text: It might sound a little twee, but just working with people who you can learn from and who you respect, and ultimately can have fun working with, it matters a ton.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Emphasizes team quality and enjoyment as a high-leverage factor in long-term performance and satisfaction.

quotes.topic_title: Leaving Etsy for SoulCycle and returning
quotes.text: We spend a lot of time of our days and our lives at work, and so doing it with people who you really value, it's awesome.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A reminder to weight “who you work with” heavily because of the sheer time investment and compounding effects.

quotes.topic_title: Leaving Etsy for SoulCycle and returning
quotes.text: I have one memory that we used to have an engineer who used to be a standup comedian, and so that really pushed the boundaries of what a standup meant every day.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A concrete example of how culture and small rituals can make day-to-day execution more engaging and sustainable.

quotes.topic_title: Etsy’s 2017 cultural shift under new CEO
quotes.text: Just to use a small example, we had had a pretty entrenched consensus-based culture, where we would really debate a lot of decisions and a lot of features.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete operating-model pattern (consensus-driven decision-making) that can slow product execution.

quotes.topic_title: Etsy’s 2017 cultural shift under new CEO
quotes.text: On the other hand, not fast.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A crisp tradeoff statement: consensus can improve quality but often sacrifices speed.

quotes.topic_title: Etsy’s 2017 cultural shift under new CEO
quotes.text: When you have your identity tied up in the company and what you do, and then you're kind of being asked or you realize that you need to change how you're working, it can feel pretty existential.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Explains the emotional mechanism behind resistance to change—process change can feel like identity threat.

quotes.topic_title: Etsy’s 2017 cultural shift under new CEO
quotes.text: The reality is it's a business, and we needed to get faster at launching features, improving the experience, and ultimately, having a predictable way to drive GMS, gross merchandise sales, which is our north star KPI.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Connects operating changes to a measurable business outcome and a clear north-star metric (GMS).

quotes.topic_title: Etsy’s 2017 cultural shift under new CEO
quotes.text: Yeah, I mean the first thing I'll say is it was a hard transition, and I was personally fortunate in the sense that the transition you're speaking of in 2017 also happened to coincide with rounds of layoffs.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Grounds the cultural shift in a specific, high-stakes example (layoffs) that often accompanies transformation.

quotes.topic_title: How leadership drove change: KPI and narrative
quotes.text: One thing that is just such a standout is having... And I mentioned GMS as our north star KPI, just having that, being absolutely front and center, being the drumbeat that we talk about in every meeting, the measuring stick that we measure the success of launches against. And maybe it's a bit surprising, but we didn't have that type of clarity in the past.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Shows how a single, consistently repeated north-star metric can align teams and evaluate launches—and that many orgs lack this clarity.

quotes.topic_title: How leadership drove change: KPI and narrative
quotes.text: If you can't really articulate why this thing matters to driving GMS and the type of timeframe that we're talking about, be it a quarter or 12 months out, and different projects will contribute in different ways.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A practical prioritization test: tie work to the north-star metric and a concrete time horizon.

quotes.topic_title: How leadership drove change: KPI and narrative
quotes.text: The other thing to me is bringing an outside in perspective, really benchmarking against your competitors and your competitive set.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Encourages an “outside-in” operating model that grounds decisions in competitive reality, not internal narratives.

quotes.topic_title: How leadership drove change: KPI and narrative
quotes.text: The old adage of you need to say something three times before people understand it. I would wager you need to say it another three times before they internalize it.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder that change communication requires far more repetition than leaders expect.

quotes.topic_title: How leadership drove change: KPI and narrative
quotes.text: If you can marry those two things, I think that's an incredibly powerful combination.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Summarizes a change-leadership formula: combine KPI clarity with a consistently repeated narrative.

quotes.topic_title: Etsy guiding principles and product operating mindset
quotes.text: one of them is around digging deeper, and that really speaks to aiming to really understand the why behind a change, to really push on the insights that we're learning through qual or quant research, or other inputs that we might be looking at in order to make the best decision possible with the information we have at the time.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A practical decision-making principle: prioritize root-cause understanding and triangulate insights from multiple research inputs before acting.

quotes.topic_title: Etsy guiding principles and product operating mindset
quotes.text: Another example of a principle is minimizing waste.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A guiding product-development mindset that frames work selection and continuation around waste reduction.

quotes.topic_title: Etsy guiding principles and product operating mindset
quotes.text: It aligns with how we think about product development, which is, we want to know, is the work we're doing adding value to the customer and the business?
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A simple, reusable evaluation test for prioritization: value must accrue to both customers and the business.

quotes.topic_title: Etsy guiding principles and product operating mindset
quotes.text: And so being able to say, "No, this is no longer valuable, we need to move on to the next thing," has been something that's served us really well.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Counteracts sunk-cost bias by explicitly endorsing stopping low-value work as a core capability.

quotes.topic_title: Etsy guiding principles and product operating mindset
quotes.text: Ultimately, we are quite a small team. There's just over 2,000 people in the business, and if you then scale back to engineering and product, we're not big. And so we have to be really diligent about how we're investing our time and our resources in order to be successful.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A concrete scale/data point used to justify a disciplined operating model around time and resource allocation.

quotes.topic_title: COVID shock: masks, seller mobilization, retention focus
quotes.text: we went to sleep one day with our typical April traffic, typical April sales, and then it was Black Friday overnight.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A vivid data-point-like comparison that captures how abruptly demand can spike and why teams need rapid-response operating modes.

quotes.topic_title: COVID shock: masks, seller mobilization, retention focus
quotes.text: we did something that far as I know we've never done an Etsy's past, which is we put out a call to our sellers to say, "Now's the time. Now's the time to make face masks if you can."
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A concrete playbook move: explicitly mobilize your supply-side community during a sudden demand shock.

quotes.topic_title: COVID shock: masks, seller mobilization, retention focus
quotes.text: Every day there would be standups. "What's happening? What do we need to change?"
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A lightweight crisis methodology: daily inspection-and-adaptation loops to keep pace with fast-changing conditions.

quotes.topic_title: COVID shock: masks, seller mobilization, retention focus
quotes.text: And so just getting back to good old-fashioned know your customer, what do they need from you at that moment was just a really kind of powerful thing that took away from that time.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A reminder that direct customer outreach and situational needs assessment can outperform abstract planning during volatility.

quotes.topic_title: COVID shock: masks, seller mobilization, retention focus
quotes.text: We got a huge influx of new or reactivated buyers. How do we keep them around? How do we make sure that the product does a little bit more work to retain them, and can really have hooks that bring them back time and again?
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A retention-focused mental model: after acquisition surges, shift to building product “hooks” that create repeat behavior beyond the initial use case.

quotes.topic_title: Leading teams through COVID and retention measurement
quotes.text: We just tried a lot of stuff.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Highlights an iterative, experimental approach to leadership during uncertainty—rapidly testing practices rather than assuming a single best process.

quotes.topic_title: Leading teams through COVID and retention measurement
quotes.text: And at a certain point we realized all we're talking about is exactly the same things. Nobody wants to be on more calls and more video video chats.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that more check-ins can become counterproductive, signaling when to reduce meeting load instead of increasing it.

quotes.topic_title: Leading teams through COVID and retention measurement
quotes.text: And so we just continued to evolve, and really try to keep a pulse on what the team needs.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Emphasizes continuous calibration of team rituals based on real needs rather than fixed schedules or assumptions.

quotes.topic_title: Leading teams through COVID and retention measurement
quotes.text: So definitely wasn't a one size fits all solution.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Actionable people-management principle: tailor support and processes to individual circumstances instead of applying uniform policies.

quotes.topic_title: Leading teams through COVID and retention measurement
quotes.text: Instead of someone making a purchase in that visit or in a week, you're looking at do they come back in 30 days, in 60 days, in 90 days?
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A concrete measurement framework for retention/frequency work that forces longer evaluation windows than typical short-horizon A/B testing.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace fundamentals: seller roots to buyer experience
quotes.text: And we really immersed ourselves in who sellers are, what they need, and how what they need maybe differs from what the solutions that they can find elsewhere.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A practical marketplace-building approach: deeply understand one side’s unique needs relative to existing alternatives before scaling solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace fundamentals: seller roots to buyer experience
quotes.text: Back in the day, we were doing studio visits with sellers. We were going to their workshops, we were going to their homes. We were seeing how they make items, we were seeing how they package and ship them out.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Concrete, replicable research tactics for building supply-side empathy and uncovering operational pain points.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace fundamentals: seller roots to buyer experience
quotes.text: We were bringing them into the office when we were running hack weeks to say, "Hey, we've got this crazy idea. Is this interesting?" So trying to involve them in the product development process to the extent that it was reasonable or feasible.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A co-creation methodology: validate ideas with real marketplace participants early and often, even during rapid prototyping cycles.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace fundamentals: seller roots to buyer experience
quotes.text: And then the next phase and the more recent phase has been, how do we create a world-class buyer experience that ultimately drives sales for our sellers? Because when you have over 100 million items, all of which are unique, you've got a different challenge than when you have 10,000 SKUs that you could kind of find anywhere or on many retailers.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A scaling mental model: shift from supply immersion to buyer experience as inventory explodes in uniqueness and complexity.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace fundamentals: seller roots to buyer experience
quotes.text: For example, customer reviews play a big role in our experience, but they play a heightened role given the things I mentioned, right? Unique inventory from a seller that is maybe an independent person who is a single entrepreneur, it's one person.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A trust-building lever: in marketplaces with unknown, independent sellers and unique items, reviews become disproportionately important.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing supply vs demand and who to prioritize
quotes.text: Because if you've got supply without demand, then you don't really have a marketplace. If you've got demand and no supply to meet it, then you also don't have a marketplace. So there's this flip-flop between, do you have enough supply to satiate the demand you have? And playing that out is certainly, I feel like art, not necessarily strictly science.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A practical mental model for marketplace operators: balancing supply and demand is an ongoing, non-linear “flip-flop” that requires judgment, not just analytics.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing supply vs demand and who to prioritize
quotes.text: And the place we're in at the moment is the job of a marketplace, even pre the technology definition of a marketplace is a seller will go there to make sales. And if they're not making sales, they probably won't go to that marketplace.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Clarifies the core retention loop for the supply side: sellers stay only if the marketplace reliably produces sales.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing supply vs demand and who to prioritize
quotes.text: That doesn't mean that every single team is working on building features for buyers because it doesn't work. Not least because you have a limited piece of real estate marketplace. And if you have too many teams working on it at one time, you'll end up getting in each other's way, and you won't be that productive.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Counterintuitive org design guidance: even if buyers are critical, over-concentrating teams on one surface creates coordination drag and reduces output.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing supply vs demand and who to prioritize
quotes.text: But really back to the GMS is the north star, GMS represents a buyer buying from a seller. So it doesn't necessarily say build only for one of your audiences or one of your customers, but it says that that's really the job to be done here is helping facilitate that transaction.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A measurable “north star” framing that aligns both sides of the marketplace around the transaction rather than picking a single side to optimize.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing supply vs demand and who to prioritize
quotes.text: And I think it's also the fact that we as the marketplace, and I'm curious if this was true at Airbnb as well, but we have the insight into information, into data, that an individual seller won't.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Highlights a key marketplace advantage: centralized data can be used to guide sellers toward actions they couldn’t infer from their own limited view.

quotes.topic_title: Supply constraints by category and seller guidance
quotes.text: At the high level, we have 100 million items. So if you take that number at face value, you would think we do not have a supply constraint. We want to drive buyers to that supply. When you dig in maybe a more category, subcategory, sub subcategory level, that's where we do start to see pockets where, maybe we want to increase the type and the amount of inventory we have in wall decor.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A practical way to diagnose supply constraints: zoom from marketplace-wide metrics down to subcategory/query-level “pockets” where constraints actually appear.

quotes.topic_title: Supply constraints by category and seller guidance
quotes.text: Ultimately, really thinking about, how do we help buyers choose? Because that's when you have 100 million items and even in a sub subcategory or for a specific search query, you still generally have a lot of results to choose from. How do you distinguish one item or one seller from another, based on the needs that you have? When is it going to arrive? How much does it cost? Is it this size or that size?
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Reframes the core marketplace problem from “more supply” to “better choice architecture,” emphasizing decision-driving attributes like delivery time, price, and size.

quotes.topic_title: Supply constraints by category and seller guidance
quotes.text: Back to that data-driven point, right? If we can clearly articulate that if you show more photos, you will help buyers understand your item in new ways, in deeper ways, then you're more likely to make a sale.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Actionable seller guidance model: use data to connect a specific behavior change (more photos) to a clear buyer benefit and conversion outcome.

quotes.topic_title: Supply constraints by category and seller guidance
quotes.text: The challenge is often, we have so many things that we want our sellers to do. What's the most important thing for them to do right now?
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Highlights prioritization as the bottleneck in seller enablement—focus recommendations on the single highest-leverage action at a given moment.

quotes.topic_title: Supply constraints by category and seller guidance
quotes.text: And that maybe changes somewhat seasonally. We're slowly starting to get towards the holiday season. And that just has a heightened purchase. It's a heightened time of purchasing. And contrast that with when it's around Mother's Day, maybe different type of inventory works really well. And so we need different inputs from our sellers.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A methodology for dynamic seller guidance: rotate priorities based on seasonal demand shifts (e.g., holidays vs. Mother’s Day) to maximize seller time ROI.

quotes.topic_title: Conversion wins: reviews, nudges, and trust signals
quotes.text: And one of the ways that worked best is exactly what you shared, where in the search experience, when someone came and searched, we just defaulted the search results to only show you instantly bookable listings.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete conversion tactic: change the default experience to steer supply-side behavior and increase buyer conversion.

quotes.topic_title: Conversion wins: reviews, nudges, and trust signals
quotes.text: We're often surprised by what works in an outsized way and what we think is going to be a knock it out of the park success, ends up being of minimal value.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A reminder to rely on experimentation because intuition about impact is frequently wrong.

quotes.topic_title: Conversion wins: reviews, nudges, and trust signals
quotes.text: And so really trying to lean into, well, what does it look like in a buyer's hand, in a buyer's home?
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A practical mental model for improving conversion on unique items: prioritize real-world context over polished listing imagery.

quotes.topic_title: Conversion wins: reviews, nudges, and trust signals
quotes.text: And then the other side is really leaning into maybe more the behavioral economic tactics of just helping buyers make decisions. Signals and nudges is how you'll see it referred to in literature.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A clear framing for conversion work: apply behavioral-econ “signals and nudges” to reduce decision friction.

quotes.topic_title: Conversion wins: reviews, nudges, and trust signals
quotes.text: And we've seen great success in elevating little snippets of information that really help a buyer understand, "There is actually only one of these. Well, that's good information to know."
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: An actionable UI pattern: surface scarcity and other key facts as glanceable snippets to boost confidence and conversion.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Customers always seem to want to give you their data in the messiest possible CSV file, and building a spreadsheet importer becomes a never ending sync for your engineering and support resources.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a common product trap: underestimating the ongoing engineering/support cost of DIY data importers.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You keep adding features to your spreadsheet importer, the customers keep running into issues. Six months later, you're fixing yet another date conversion edge case bug.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A vivid example of how edge cases compound over time, making “simple” import features a maintenance sink.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Spreadsheet import is such an awful experience in so many products.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Calls out a widespread UX failure area that can block activation and onboarding success.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Customers get frustrated by useless messages like error on line 53, and never end up getting started with your product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable reminder that poor error messaging can directly prevent users from reaching first value.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: one of the biggest wins for Airbnb's search experience was this very small idea of just, what if you open each listing in the search results in a new tab, and ended up converting 1%, like increasing conversion by 1%?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example that small UX changes can yield meaningful conversion lifts, encouraging teams to test “tiny” ideas.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation surprises and Etsy’s testing philosophy
quotes.text: Oftentimes I think about effort and reward. So it might be a smallish GMS win or conversion rate win, but it was a one line text change.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A practical prioritization lens: small, low-effort changes (like copy) can deliver meaningful marketplace impact.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation surprises and Etsy’s testing philosophy
quotes.text: We've long and continued to invest in sustainability, and the text change was in our cart where we call out Etsy offsets carbon emissions from every delivery. And just adding that simple line of text was something that, like I said, really resonated with our buyers and the type of customer that comes to Etsy, and really drove conversion.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A concrete example of values-based messaging in a high-intent moment (cart) producing outsized conversion lift.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation surprises and Etsy’s testing philosophy
quotes.text: Because to some degree, or maybe the way I think about experimentation, that's the highest bar. That proves with near absolute certainty that there's a causal relationship between the change you made and the KPI that you want to move.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A clear articulation of why A/B tests are the gold standard: establishing causality between a change and a KPI movement.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation surprises and Etsy’s testing philosophy
quotes.text: But I think that it maybe misses the point in some changes or some areas where you are working towards a bigger net new thing or this specific change won't really be indicative of the greater whole you're building towards.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A counterpoint to over-reliance on A/B tests: some initiatives require validation methods that reflect longer-term or holistic outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation surprises and Etsy’s testing philosophy
quotes.text: When we're collecting inputs from sellers, we just simply don't feel it's appropriate to not either show or honor.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A principle for marketplace trust: certain seller-facing changes shouldn’t be randomized, pushing teams toward alternative evaluation methods.

quotes.topic_title: Acquisition: early seller growth, SEO, and referrals
quotes.text: On the buyer side, we really leveraged the fact that we have a ton of inventory. And to some degree, it ends up being quite a long tail of inventory where we can meet really niche and specific needs. And so that lends itself really well to thinking about SEO, lends itself really well to thinking about Google Shopping, where someone is not on Etsy, but is often looking for something either somewhat or very specific.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A practical acquisition playbook: use long-tail inventory to win intent-driven channels like SEO and Google Shopping.

quotes.topic_title: Acquisition: early seller growth, SEO, and referrals
quotes.text: I mean, yes, and a seller is a buyer.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A memorable marketplace mental model: supply-side users can also seed demand, creating a flywheel.

quotes.topic_title: Acquisition: early seller growth, SEO, and referrals
quotes.text: What we saw, it was a different time. And so I think we maybe didn't value a new buyer, for example, in the way we do today. Because to some degree, you're unlocking future value. They make a single purchase, and then the bet is over time they'll go on to make subsequent purchases.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A cautionary lesson for referral programs: success depends on correctly valuing LTV, not just first purchase value.

quotes.topic_title: Acquisition: early seller growth, SEO, and referrals
quotes.text: And that may seem like a very small financial outlay to get started, but it's a little bit of a barrier. And the more we can do to remove those, the higher chance that someone will either become a seller or list more items.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Actionable growth lever: reduce even small activation frictions to increase conversion and ongoing supply creation.

quotes.topic_title: Acquisition: early seller growth, SEO, and referrals
quotes.text: So we really leaned into that as the currency for the seller referral program.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A concrete tactic: use product-native credits (listing fees) as referral incentives aligned with the core action.

quotes.topic_title: Retention loops: favorites, updates feed, notifications
quotes.text: But how do we think about the habit loop of if you take an action, what's the trigger and then what's the reward?
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Introduces a practical retention framework (habit loop) for designing product mechanics around user actions.

quotes.topic_title: Retention loops: favorites, updates feed, notifications
quotes.text: You favorite an item. That's a pretty strong ish... Of course, adding it to your cart or maybe purchasing it, that's the strongest of signals, but you've shown intent.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Highlights how to treat lightweight actions (favorites) as intent signals and rank them against stronger signals like cart/purchase.

quotes.topic_title: Retention loops: favorites, updates feed, notifications
quotes.text: So what can we do with that information? We can then say, "The seller put it on sale. You should come back and check it out. This is selling out. There's only one of this item left. You showed some intent, you might want to come back and get it." And that's just one example of trying to close those loops.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Gives concrete examples of closing retention loops by turning intent into timely, value-based re-engagement triggers (sale/scarcity).

quotes.topic_title: Retention loops: favorites, updates feed, notifications
quotes.text: And that's where we've worked on things like, we call it the updates feed, essentially a feed of activity that you've taken, that we're demonstrating how it's changed, what's new, and then pulling in the tried and true tactic of push notifications to make you aware of that, such that you're using your phone all the time.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Describes a retention mechanism combining an updates feed with push notifications to surface changes to items/actions users already care about.

quotes.topic_title: Retention loops: favorites, updates feed, notifications
quotes.text: And so those are examples where really leaning into that habit loop framework has helped us understand, we've got a lot of this activity. How do we close the loop? How do we make it really valuable for our buyers?
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Reinforces the methodology: start from existing user activity and systematically design loops that deliver buyer value.

quotes.topic_title: Differentiation vs Amazon/eBay: brand and marketplace integrity
quotes.text: And so I think that as the core nugget, combined with how we think about policies, and our way to some degree, maintain the integrity of the marketplace, those two things combined do set us apart.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A defensibility framework: differentiation comes from pairing a distinct brand with policies that actively protect marketplace integrity.

quotes.topic_title: Differentiation vs Amazon/eBay: brand and marketplace integrity
quotes.text: I think it is the supply.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A clear mental model that brand positioning in marketplaces is ultimately anchored in what inventory exists (and doesn’t).

quotes.topic_title: Differentiation vs Amazon/eBay: brand and marketplace integrity
quotes.text: And so just being really clear about what's okay to sell and what's not okay, I think does really differentiate us.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for marketplace operators: differentiation can be created by explicit supply rules and enforcement, not just marketing.

quotes.topic_title: Differentiation vs Amazon/eBay: brand and marketplace integrity
quotes.text: But to the point where we are now, the statement we have is keep commerce human.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A memorable positioning line that can serve as a decision filter for product, policy, and brand choices.

quotes.topic_title: Differentiation vs Amazon/eBay: brand and marketplace integrity
quotes.text: Maybe never say never, but an item getting dropped off by a drone and a person never touches it, that doesn't feel very Etsy.
quotes.speaker: Tim Holley
quotes.context: A counterintuitive example showing how a strong brand may intentionally avoid “better” logistics if it undermines the marketplace’s identity.
